EDITORIAL COMMENT
FALSE ECONOMY
VER since the driveway from the Barn to Gilman Hall was
closed to vehicular traffic, campus motorists have been forced
to use the road behind the engineering buildings, when entering the
grounds from Charles Street. This cinder trail, constructed of furnace debris, has never proved satisfactory and has been a constant
source of complaint. Its uneven surface anll deep ruts have been the
causes of continual grumbling from automobile drivers.
From time to time, this poor condition has been temporarily remedied by summoning a corps of workmen to fill in the holes and smooth •
the surface. But, after every rainfall, the road always returns to its
former condition. Heavy trucks and passenger automobiles grind the
cinders into the soft mud and form deep ruts which rival the shell
holes of No Man's Land.
The present cinder road certainly adds ncithing to the beauty of
the campus. and its constant repairing must form an important item
. in the list of University expenditures. We feel that the present policy
of attempting to save Money by maintaining this makeshift driveway
will prove far from economical. •
A new, concrete road would soon pay for itself. The appearance of the campus would be greatly improved and the curses of irate •
motorists would be silenced.

PRINCESS AND STUDENTS
NPERGRADUATE students could easily sympathize with the
plight of Princess Jacqueline, the "talking dog". Unused to
the mysteries of university life, the princess' mistress unfortunately selected a day in examination week for the exhibition of her loquacious
canine. Instead of speaking her piece before theprofessors' investigating committee, her royal highness was Afflicted with a severe case of
stage fright and proceeded to utter only unintelligible yelps and barks.'
Meanwhile, on another part of the campus, the undergraduates
were suffering a fate similar to that of the French bulldog. Confronted with long lists of mimeographed questions, the harassed scholars trepthled and grew pale. :Nauseated expressions overspread their
countenances as they crunched lead pencils between their teeth. While
the princess was howling "waw,wav.-,waw's", the students were fran•
tically 'scribbling 4n their examination books. s
Judging from the newspaper accounts, and the white slip posted
on the class room door jambs, neither the princess nor the undergraduates were able to convince the pedagogues that they assess an unusual amount of knowledge. Princess Jacqueline's vocabulary shrank
to a mere series of howls, while the scholars' amount of learning seems
to have been equally scant.
The tragic feature of the story is this:—whereas the students
could drown their sorrows at the Second Cotillon, the poor little princess had to content herself with a hard, dry dog biscuit and a little
water. But that, after all, is a dog's life.

the most prosaic university campus in America.

FALSE ECONOMY
VER since the driveway from the Barn to Gilman Hall was
closed to vehicular traffic, campus motorists have been forced
to use the road behind the engineering buildings, when entering the
grounds from Charles Street. This cinder trail, constructed of furnace debris, has never proved satisfactory and has been a constant
source of complaint. Its uneven surface anll deep ruts have been the
causes of continual grumbling from automobile drivers.
From time to time, this poor condition has been temporarily remedied by summoning a corps of workmen to fill in the holes and smooth •
the surface. But, after every rainfall, the road always returns to its
former condition. Heavy trucks and passenger automobiles grind the
cinders into the soft mud and form deep ruts which rival the shell
holes of No Man's Land.
The present cinder road certainly adds ncithing to the beauty of
the campus. and its constant repairing must form an important item
. in the list of University expenditures. We feel that the present policy
of attempting to save Money by maintaining this makeshift driveway
will prove far from economical. •
A new, concrete road would soon pay for itself. The appearance of the campus would be greatly improved and the curses of irate •
motorists would be silenced.

PRINCESS AND STUDENTS
NPERGRADUATE students could easily sympathize with the
plight of Princess Jacqueline, the "talking dog". Unused to
the mysteries of university life, the princess' mistress unfortunately selected a day in examination week for the exhibition of her loquacious
canine. Instead of speaking her piece before theprofessors' investigating committee, her royal highness was Afflicted with a severe case of
stage fright and proceeded to utter only unintelligible yelps and barks.'
Meanwhile, on another part of the campus, the undergraduates
were suffering a fate similar to that of the French bulldog. Confronted with long lists of mimeographed questions, the harassed scholars trepthled and grew pale. :Nauseated expressions overspread their
countenances as they crunched lead pencils between their teeth. While
the princess was howling "waw,wav.-,waw's", the students were fran•
tically 'scribbling 4n their examination books. s
Judging from the newspaper accounts, and the white slip posted
on the class room door jambs, neither the princess nor the undergraduates were able to convince the pedagogues that they assess an unusual amount of knowledge. Princess Jacqueline's vocabulary shrank
to a mere series of howls, while the scholars' amount of learning seems
to have been equally scant.
The tragic feature of the story is this:—whereas the students
could drown their sorrows at the Second Cotillon, the poor little princess had to content herself with a hard, dry dog biscuit and a little
water. But that, after all, is a dog's life.
